Associationism: An Integrative Synthesis 
Associationism, like functionalism, was less a rigid school of psychology than an influential way of thinking. Associationism examines how events or ideas can become 
associated with one another in the mind to result in a form of learning. For example, 
associations may result from contiguity (associating things that tend to occur together 
at about the same time), similarity (associating things with similar features or proper 
ties), or contrast (associating things that seem to show polarities, such as hot/cold, 
light/dark, day/night). 
In the late 1800s, associationist Hermann Ebbinghaus was the first 
experimenter to apply associationist principles systematically. Specifically, Ebbinghaus 
studied his own mental processes. He counted his errors and recorded his response 
times. Through his self-observations, Ebbinghaus studied how people learn and remember material through rehearsal. Rehearsal is the conscious repetition of to-be-Iearned 
material. Among other findings, he found that frequent repetition can fix mental as 
sociations more firmly in memory. Thus, repetition aids in learning 
Another influential associationist, Edward Lee Thorndike, held 
that the role of "satisfaction" is the key to forming associations. Thorndike termed
